ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

RSS COURAGEOUS
(Collision with ANL Indonesia)


    1. Dr Ong Chit Chung asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (a) what are the causes of the collision between RSS Courageous and merchant vessel ANL Indonesia and (b) whether follow-up actions are being taken to prevent such incidents in the future.

    2. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (a) if he will provide a status update of the recent collision between RSS Courageous and ANL Indonesia; (b) what measures are being taken to assist the family members of the deceased, especially on a longer term basis; and (c) how will the Republic of Singapore Navy ensure that this accident will not leave a psychological scar on existing navy personnel and impact the recruitment of potential navy recruits.

    3. Mr Chiam See Tong asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence if he will explain how the collision between the naval vessel RSS Courageous and the container vessel ANL Indonesia occurred in Singapore waters recently.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Defence (Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your permission, I will take the three questions by Dr Ong Chit Chung, Mdm Ho Geok Choo and Mr Chiam See Tong together.

    Mr Speaker: Yes, carry on.

    Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, the collision between the RSS Courageous and the merchant ship ANL Indonesia was a most tragic event for the Navy, the SAF and Singapore. On behalf of the Singapore Government, I offer our deepest condolences to the families of 1SG Seah Ai Leng, 1SG Heng Sock Ling, 2SG Chua Bee Lin and CPL Goh Hui Ling.

Column: 1997

This has been a very difficult time for their families and we share in their grief and sorrow.

    It is to be expected that Singaporeans want to know what happened that night and what caused the accident. The investigation by the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore is ongoing. MINDEF's own Higher Board of Inquiry is still in the process of putting up its report. It would not be appropriate for me to give a full public account at this point. But I will give Members some facts of the situation leading up to the collision.

    RSS Courageous, an Anti-Submarine Warfare Patrol Vessel, was conducting a regular operational patrol in Singapore territorial waters. This is part of the Navy's mission of safeguarding our territorial sovereignty. RSS Courageous was in the waters off Pedra Branca. There has been a spate of violations of our territorial waters at Pedra Branca by foreign state vessels recently. There were a number of violations in the two weeks before the incident, and there have been several since then.

    On the night of the collision, ANL Indonesia was heading out of the Singapore Straits towards the South China Sea. RSS Courageous was sailing in the opposite direction. The two vessels were headed in the general direction towards each other. RSS Courageous had detected ANL Indonesia on radar. ANL Indonesia was also visually sighted by the duty watch personnel on board RSS Courageous. The two vessels subsequently came into a close quarter situation, and both took action to try to avoid a collision. But unfortunately the collision took place. ANL Indonesia rammed into the right rear section of RSS Courageous and a portion of the tail end of the Patrol Vessel was sheared off. This portion included the aft mess, where four servicewomen who were off duty at the time were resting.

    The Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore (MPA) is carrying out an independent investigation into the incident, and MINDEF has given MPA our fullest cooperation in this investigation.

Column: 1998

The Commanding Officer and crew members of RSS Courageous have been interviewed by MPA. MPA expects to complete its full investigation by the end of the month and will make known its findings in due course. Separately, MINDEF has convened a Higher Board of Inquiry to determine what happened on the part of RSS Courageous. Until the various investigations are completed, we do not have a complete picture of the events that happened that night. At this juncture, it would not be appropriate for us to speculate on how and why the collision happened, or to apportion responsibility for the collision.

    I would like to reassure the House that MINDEF takes a very serious view of this incident and we will take close heed of the findings of the inquiries and rectify any problems that are identified. In the meantime, the RSN has taken immediate steps to reinforce the existing emphasis on safety and professional training. It is increasing checks on shipboard practices and operational training, and conducting a thorough review of its procedures and processes.

    Safety has always been a matter of high priority for the SAF. There are inherent risks involved in military activity, and we take every precaution to mitigate such risks with intensive and comprehensive training of our people and a thorough system for risk management. We cannot entirely rule out accidents no matter how safety conscious we may be, because other elements such as errors of judgement and mechanical failures sometimes come into play. Whatever the cause of the tragic accident involving RSS Courageous, the SAF will use the findings to make further improvements so that we further reduce the risk of another accident.

    We can be proud of the way the crew of RSS Courageous responded in the extreme circumstances after the collision and the way the whole Navy has responded since then. It underscores the capability, resolve, and professionalism of the RSN, and its esprit de corps. In the face of difficult sea conditions, the

Column: 1999

Commanding Officer and crew of Courageous fought to stabilise their severely damaged ship, while tending to injured crewmates and searching for those who were missing. They displayed their mettle in the face of grave adversity and professionally and resolutely carried out what they were trained to do.

    A search and rescue operation was launched immediately after the collision. In the immediate aftermath of the collision, the Police Coast Guard provided critical assistance. Over a period of ten days, the RSN and RSAF conducted an extensive and intensive search and rescue operation. We received valuable assistance from the Indonesian armed forces. In coordinating the search and rescue operation, the RSN also sought the assistance of the Malaysian armed forces for the search of the Johor coastal areas as we wanted to cover every possibility. We deeply appreciate the assistance and co-operation our neighbouring countries extended to our Search and Rescue operation. I should also note here the dedicated efforts of the salvage crew in their attempts to recover the sheared-off portion of RSS Courageous under adverse monsoon conditions.

    We know how difficult this must be for the families who have lost their loved ones and we are deeply sorry for their loss. After the incident, the RSN has been keeping in close touch with the families to give them support and provide assistance. Professional counsellors have also been helping them through this difficult period. MINDEF will continue to provide the necessary support to the families of the four servicewomen.

    This has certainly been a difficult period for the RSN and the SAF. But it is also in such moments of adversity that the real quality and character of the organisation and its people shine through. The RSN plays a vital role in protecting the sovereignty and territorial integrity of Singapore's waters. We cannot shy away from our responsibilities in the face of

Column: 2000

tragedy. The RSN will continue to conduct patrols to safeguard Singapore's territorial waters. I have every confidence that the RSN and SAF will overcome this tragic event and continue to discharge their mission with even greater determination.

    Dr Ong Chit Chung (Jurong): Sir, I want to express our deepest sympathies and condolences to the bereaved families and I am sure the RSN will put all this behind it, and learn and move forward. I want to ask whether the Deputy Prime Minister could clarify the Malaysian statement that Singapore had asked Malaysia for permission to conduct search and rescue operation in the waters off Pedra Branca. What is our response to the Malaysian request for such joint patrols?

    Further, could the Deputy Prime Minister clarify what he mentioned earlier, ie, there was a spate of violations of our territorial waters at Pedra Branca by foreign state vessels recently? Could the Deputy Prime Minister please tell this House what actually happened?

    Dr Tony Tan Keng Yam: Sir, the incident happened in Singapore territorial waters off Pedra Branca and Singapore did not ask permission from Malaysia to conduct search and rescue operation. To put this in the proper context, in accordance with well-established international search and rescue procedures, there is an arrangement for aircraft to enter foreign airspace in a search area to conduct search and rescue operation, if necessary. This requires prior diplomatic clearance to enter foreign airspace. For this particular operation, both Indonesia and Malaysia granted Singapore prior diplomatic clearance to enter their airspace to conduct search and rescue operation.

    As for joint patrols, there is no question of joint patrols in Singapore's territorial waters. Sir, as you know, the Singapore and Malaysian governments have agreed to refer the issue of Pedra Branca to the International Court of Justice. In fact, both sides have agreed to proceed with the signing of the special agreement on 6th February to

Column: 2001

International Court of Justice. Unfortunately, Malaysian government vessels from both their navy and marine police have recently stepped up their intrusions into Pedra Branca waters and this despite the fact that the Malaysian government is aware that after the two countries agreed in 1994 to take the case to the ICJ what happened on the ground at Pedra Branca will have no bearing on the judgment by the ICJ.

    There were three violations by Malaysian state vessels over the last week of December. There were five more violations last week. In these incidents, the Malaysian vessels came close to Pedra Branca and conducted various activities. As Members know, the Malaysian media reported extensively on the 24th December 2002 incident where a Malaysian marine police patrol craft brought along a group of journalists.

    Besides these violations, it is also regrettable that the Malaysian government has seized on the tragic accident involving RSS Courageous to try to advance their claim to Pedra Branca. The Malaysian government presented a Third Party Note to the Singapore Government on 14th January 2003 protesting "the violation of Malaysia's territorial waters around the Malaysian island of Batu Putih" by RSS Courageous at the time of the collision. The TPN further stated that as the collision had taken place in Malaysian territorial waters, the Malaysian Marine Department had commenced investigations and the TPN attached forms for the Commanding Officer of RSS Courageous to submit to the Malaysian Marine Department.

    It is most unfortunate that the Malaysian government has chosen to exploit this tragic accident which can only serve to stir up emotions and make it more difficult to have an amicable settlement of the issue.

    Sir, Pedra Branca is Singapore's territory. The RSN will continue to carry out its mission of safeguarding Singapore's sovereignty and territorial integrity. The RSN will continue to patrol our territorial waters off Pedra Branca.

Column: 2002

VESSELS PASSING THROUGH SINGAPORE
(Security measures against terrorist attacks)


    4. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for Home Affairs (a) whether Singapore, as the world's largest container trans-shipment hub, is a prime target for acts of terror; and (b) what are the measures his Ministry is taking to enhance security and harden the area against terrorist attacks for vessels passing through the area.

    The Senior Minister of State for Home Affairs (Assoc. Prof. Ho Peng Kee) (for the Minister for Home Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore has the world's busiest port. The Singapore Straits is also one of the world's busiest sealanes with about 140,000 vessels a year passing through it. It is Government's top priority to ensure that incidents similar to the suicide bombing of a French flagship, the Limburgh, off Yemen on 6th October last year do not happen here.

    Sir, although newspaper reports have highlighted the likelihood of terrorists seizing a ship and crashing it into another vessel or into a refinery or port, there is currently no specific intelligence of such an attack in our ports and the sealanes around Singapore.

    Singapore waters have been free of sea robberies inclusive of terrorism for the past 12 years as a result of relentless efforts put in by our security agencies. But we are conscious of evolving developments and are constantly looking for ways to protect ourselves against the terrorist threat. The Singapore Police Force, together with other relevant agencies, has audited and reviewed the security measures at our ports and other landing points. We have introduced enhanced security measures. These measures include ensuring security of our ports' perimeters, controlling access via security passes, checking of personnel, baggage and vehicles, closed-circuit monitoring of port facilities

Column: 2003

guards. These are landward security measures.

    On the seaward side, the three lead agencies, ie, the Police Coast Guard, the Republic of Singapore Navy and the Maritime and Port Authority of Singapore, work together and have introduced additional security measures to safeguard vessels in our waters. Sensitive areas such as the waters around petrochemical installations and the approaches to them used by tankers are declared out of bounds to all other traffic. The Navy has also been escorting certain high-value merchant vessels such as oil and gas tankers, large container vessels and cruise ships through the Singapore Straits. The Police Coast Guard (PCG) has increased its deployment by 30% since September 11. The PCG is also in the process of upgrading its surveillance capabilities and acquiring newer and better patrol boats.

    Sir, Singapore was among the first few countries to sign up as a pilot port under the Container Security initiative to screen sea containers exported or trans-shipped to the US. As part of the initiative, US container security officers would be deployed in Singapore to work together with our enforcement officers to jointly target and prescreen containers bound for the US. In addition, Singapore will be deploying radiographic scanners at our ports from next month. The scanners will be used by our officers to boost their detecting capability for containers entering Singapore and help move containers in our ports in a more secure and expeditious fashion.



Column: 2003

JOB SEEKERS EMPLOYMENT ASSISTANCE
(Particulars)


    5. Mr Charles Chong asked the Minister for Manpower for a breakdown of the number of job seekers (a) seeking employment assistance for the period January to December 2002 from (i) his Ministry, (ii) each of the five Community

Column: 2004

Development Councils and (iii) each of the four self-help groups (namely the Chinese Development Assistance Council, Mendaki, Sinda and Eurasian Association); and (b) successfully placed by the respective organisations as a percentage of the number.

    6. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Manpower (a) if he will provide a status update on (i) the unemployment situation by occupation, age group and qualification (ii) job vacancies and their distribution in the various industries and (iii) the extent and success of job creation; and (b) what other measures will the Government consider to change the mindset of (i) employers with regard to employing those above the age of 45 years and (ii) potential job seekers, especially those who have been retrenched and are above the age of 45 years.

    7. Dr Mohamad Maliki bin Osman asked the Minister for Manpower if he will provide an update on the success of the 'People for Jobs' programme implemented by his Ministry, including the number of people who have enrolled in programmes such as the Skills Redevelopment Programme and the rate of job placement for these individuals.

    8. Dr Mohamad Maliki bin Osman asked the Minister for Manpower (a) what is the number of people who have sought assistance for jobs from the Community Development Councils (CDCs) in 2002 and how many of them have successfully gained employment; and (b) what is being done to further improve the job placement rates for retrenched Singaporeans who have sought help from the CDCs.

    The Minister of State for Manpower (Dr Ng Eng Hen) (for the Minister for Manpower): Mr Speaker, with your permission, I would like to take Questions 5 to 8 as they cover related issues on unemployment.

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

Column: 2005



    Dr Ng Eng Hen: In December 2001, MOM established the "Distributed CareerLink Network". This comprises 13 organisations - the five Community Development Councils (CDCs), the five self-help groups of MENDAKI, the Eurasian Association, SINDA, CDAC and the Association of Muslim Professionals (AMP), as well as the Singapore National Employers Federation (SNEF), National Trades Union Congress (NTUC), and the Singapore Professionals' and Executives' Cooperative (SPEC). This network was formed to improve employment assistance services to the unemployed. This Government and community organisations network would be more responsive to the needs of those looking for jobs.

    Mr Charles Chong and Dr Mohamad Maliki have both asked for a detailed breakdown of individual performances by the various placement agencies. I will provide data in four broad groups because they serve different communities: that of MOM itself, the CDCs, the self-help groups and others which are made up of SNEF, SPEC and NTUC. From December 2001 to November 2002, MOM provided employment assistance services to 54,600 visits from job seekers. 62% of the job seekers were provided with at least one job referral. Approximately 15% of all job seekers were placed in jobs within three months.

    In that same period, the CDCs collectively provided employment assistance to 38,310 job requests and placed about 13% of these into jobs. The corresponding figure for the self-help groups was 15,961 persons with a placement rate of 6.4%. SNEF, SPEC and NTUC together provided assistance to 8,206 job requests and placed about 19% of them.

    In total, MOM and its DCN partners attended to 117,000 job requests and helped 15,701 get jobs. This is about 13%. In 2002, 47,000 Skills Redevelopment Programme training places were taken up by 33,516 workers. Given that the number of unemployed now stands at around 80,000, these figures suggest that the majority of those looking for jobs

Column: 2006

know where to seek assistance and have made repeated visits to our Distributed CareerLink Network.

    Sir, at this juncture, let me correct the wrong impression that only 13% of those looking for jobs are successful. I have to clarify that the Distributed CareerLink Network caters to a select group of retrenched Singaporeans who find it harder to get jobs. In fact, our reemployment data indicates that in 2001 and 2002, 60-65% of those retrenched are able to secure a job within six months of retrenchment. The re-employment rate for the quarter ending September 2002 was 67%, the highest in the last two years. This indicates that the majority of Singaporeans who have lost their jobs are realistic. They know where to go for training and indeed are able by themselves to secure new employment. Government will continue to assist those with general enabling schemes.

    And in response to Dr Maliki's request on one such scheme - the People for Jobs Traineeship Programme - I am pleased to report that more than 3,000 companies from various sectors have hired approximately 8,000 workers in 2002. This particular programme provides an incentive to encourage employers to recruit workers who are 40 years and above who may lack relevant experience for the new jobs or work environment.

    The hon. Members' questions also touch on a more important concern that other Members of this House also share: "How can we help that particular group of Singaporeans like those which the DCN serves who are at higher risk of being structurally unemployed to get jobs?"

    Sir, the figures I have provided indicate that access to services - dissemination of information about jobs and provision of training courses - appears adequate, but the actual placement of jobs for this group of workers - about 13% - could be improved. In other words, we have told this group of people where the fish are, we taught them how to fish, but the actual number who are catching fishes could be better. Why is this so?

Column: 2007



    Let me now ask the Clerk of Parliament to distribute a fact sheet (Tables (Cols. 2131-44) Nos. 1, 2, 3A, 3B and 4), which contains the data on the unemployment and vacancy situation sought by Mdm Ho Geok Choo. She has asked for a detailed list. I have provided it and I do not propose to go through the detailed list. Let me just summarise and say that while there were 72,000 unemployed residents at the end of September last year, there were over 17,000 job vacancies in various sectors. We also have nearly 450,000 foreign workers here to supplement our local workforce; in other words, 450,000 potential jobs held by foreign workers at this point of time. So, in that context, why should there be Singaporeans who are unemployed? Since its inception in January 2002, the Jobs Task Force has posed this question to ourselves and to our members who comprise CEOs of various industries, unionists, mayors, EDB, and as well as those looking for jobs.

    Let me share with you some of the common reasons given to the Jobs Task Force for this select group of workers. First of all, the pool of jobs available is relatively smaller compared to the past. We had a tremendous run - 15 years of above 7% GDP growth that created, in essence, two jobs to every Singaporean. In that climate for 15 years, even those with less skills could wait for that `dream' job. But as we have been deliberately repeating, the world has changed. No mature economy, which we are, expects to achieve such growth rates and job creation. Instead, fewer jobs will be created which will have higher value-add. Lower skilled jobs will also be available but may be in more vigorous working conditions. It would be unrealistic and indeed frustrating to wait for the best job to come along.

    In the marine industry, 30,000 jobs were created in the last five years and even now, there are about 1,300 vacancies. With overtime, the take-home pay is

Column: 2008

substantial, with a median wage of $1,800 per month, but Singaporeans shun this industry. In the retail and restaurant sectors, there are 2,000 vacancies now but these jobs are not attractive to locals. Even in the manufacturing sector, there are about 3,000 vacancies. However, some Singaporeans who qualify for these jobs do not want to work in wafer fabs because they dislike donning suits, working in clean rooms or the 12-hour shifts. Others have practical difficulties. HDB RESALE FLATS
(Reasons for devaluation)


    10. Dr Wang Kai Yuen asked the Minister for National Development (a) what are the reasons that caused the significant devaluation of the Housing and Development Board (HDB) resale flats in recent years; (b) what measures his Ministry could have taken to prevent this collapse; and (c) what measures will the Government take to ameliorate the negative equity suffered by these HDB flat owners.

Column: 2022



    The Minister for National Development (Mr Mah Bow Tan): Mr Speaker, Sir, Singapore's economy has been going through a difficult period following the Asian financial crisis in 1997. This has affected almost all sectors of our economy and the property market, which includes both private residential properties and HDB flats, has not been spared.

    Although the prices of HDB resale flats have fallen by about 29% from their peak in 1996, the decline is not as much as that for private property prices, which have fallen 37% from their peak. There are several reasons for this.

    Firstly, HDB calibrates its building programme to match the overall demand for HDB flats. When the take-up of new flats under the Registration for Flat System (RFS) was affected by the economic slowdown in the last few years, HDB cut back sharply on the construction of new HDB flats from 1998 onwards. This helped to minimise the build-up of unsold stocks, although it was still substantial due to the time lag between tender and completion of building contracts. To reduce the unsold stock, HDB has focused on selling flats through several Walk-in Selection exercises. HDB's efforts have been quite successful, and we expect to be able to substantially clear the surplus stock within the next two years.

    Secondly, HDB is mindful of the impact that new flat prices may have on the resale market. In pricing new flats, affordability is the primary consideration. But, HDB also takes into consideration the prices of comparable resale flats, and the adjustments to the prices of new flats are done more gradually, so as to minimise price fluctuations and any knock-on effect on the resale market.

    HDB has in place several financial assistance schemes to assist existing mortgagors who encounter financial difficulties in servicing their mortgage instalments. Through these measures, HDB homeowners with negative equity at the moment are under less pressure to sell their flats. In 2002, less than 100 HDB

Column: 2023

resale flat lessees sold their flat at a price lower than their outstanding mortgage loan. This is only a small fraction compared to the 39,000 resale transactions that were processed in the year.

    Property prices go through cycles. After two years of decline in 2000 and 2001, HDB resale prices remained relatively stable last year. As the economy recovers, property prices will also recover and the problem of negative equity will be minimised, if not fully resolved.

But of even greater consequence to us would have been the damage to ethnic relations in multi-racial and multi-religious Singapore, because those who were thwarted in their mission were Muslims, connected directly to Al Qaeda, and were prepared to carry out their mindless acts in the name of Islam. The Jemaah Islamiyah, if it had succeeded, would have placed Muslim Singaporeans under a glaring but uncomfortable and unenviable spotlight.

    Sir, immediately after the first arrests were made, the Government made it clear that this was not a focus on the Muslim community but on the JI, that it was not a communal threat but one concerning national security affecting all Singaporeans, underscores the point that the fabric of racial and religious harmony that we enjoy in Singapore can be easily torn apart if unfounded suspicions are allowed to affect the way non-Muslims behave towards Muslims in Singapore. For decades, we have had the foresight to build a multi-racial and multi-religious society while giving recognition to the unique flavour of each ethnic group and the values and heritage of each religious belief. It would be benign of me to simply put it that 37 years of nation building would have been in vain if we have not

Column: 2102

fortified our resolve to live as one nation, one people, regardless of race, language and religion, come what may. But the reality is that the harmony we now enjoy is fragile enough to be unzipped right down the middle, if ignited by an event such as the one that might have happened if the JI had its way.

    Hence, the White Paper serves as a wake-up call. Its recommendations require us to be on the defensive as well as to be proactive in the fight against terrorism. We have enhanced our intelligence and tightened security measures. We have passed laws to criminalise terrorist funding, and we have joined the global effort through steps, such as the signing of the International Convention for the Suppression of the Financing of Terrorism.

    But, Sir, what is equally important is the proactive role of each citizen to strengthen social cohesion and racial harmony. Such a clarion call to rally everyone is, of course, easy to make, and I have found myself grappling with the thought that if we do encounter a situation where a dastardly attack takes place, will we find ourselves asking: have we done enough - and have we done it fast enough - to maintain the integrity of the relations between our various peoples?

    To come back to the reality of the present, we know we have time, hopefully, to scrutinise what we must do. We have the IRCCs, and we are shaping the Code on Religious Harmony, and I think these are all positive moves. But we must ask ourselves, in all frankness, whether it is enough just to make symbolic visits to temples and mosques. While we take heart that good sense does prevail at leadership levels, I find myself, at times, fearful that if a group of evil and desperate persons succeed just once in breaking through our meticulous security cordon and explode their devices and cause untold damage, what would be the reaction of our own heartlanders? What would be the effect on the moderation and peace that we now enjoy?

Column: 2103



    We rightfully ask that there be more common space for the different races and that the social space where all Singaporeans can interact be expanded. The Prime Minister himself has pointed out that the downside to Muslims feeling more at ease with social activities at mosques than anywhere else is that Muslims will feel less and less of a need to mingle with other races. This is a poignant truth that the Muslim community has to ponder.

    But while we ask our Muslim friends to move closer to mainstream Singapore, at the same time, we who are the majority, must not, unwittingly or otherwise, become more vigilant towards them because of the militant ideology of the few in their midst. In as much as we want to know how the Muslim community reacts and we have asked them to speak out against terrorism, the rest of us must also not overreact, because at the end of the day, if the Muslim community feels alienated, the JI would have won the psychological battle. I am therefore heartened to note that the Government recognises that, in its efforts to identify and neutralise radical Islamic religious leaders and foreign terrorist operatives, it must not disrupt the legitimate and peaceful activities of the local Muslim community.

    Sir, this is not a fight over whose political ideology is superior. This is about a war against fanaticism, against those who want their militant brand of a religion to prevail. How else can you make of their declared position that those who defect from their cause, or who do not support their violent ways are labelled infidels? What else can you make of an organisation that thinks nothing of killing thousands, including those of their own faith?

    Is it therefore not significant to us that the plan to bomb Yishun MRT Station was foiled because of a call made by a Muslim Singaporean to the ISD? Whoever it was must have been aware that what is at stake is not a fight between Muslims and

Column: 2104

non-Muslims, but one of a cult-like organisation bent on inflicting senseless attrition versus the rest of humanity.

    This White Paper has sent the message that Singapore is no pushover in this fight. We will muster all our resources and work closely with every peace loving nation in the world. Encountering the terrorist threat needs a global effort and it cannot be done spasmodically. If Southeast Asia is the next battleground in the fight against terrorism, then regional cooperation becomes vital in our efforts to take on an organisation that has cast its tentacles across national boundaries. It took the bombings in Bali for the Indonesian government to move from self-denial to the fact that they already have the enemy within. The rest of the world watches us. Investors will not make that fine distinction between Singapore and other Southeast Asian countries, if an attack takes place anywhere in the region. When the bombs in Bali went off, some countries issued travel advisories on several Southeast Asian countries, Singapore included.

    So, Mr Deputy Speaker, when our neighbours up north, in their own wisdom, utter the "W" word in their dispute with us over water and Pedra Branca, and in the process send their own people into a frenzy, I think it is timely for us also to remind them that what we have at hand is a real war against an enemy, playing a game far more deadly than the hysteria we have to bear with from them occasionally.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Sin Boon Ann (Tampines): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, thank you for allowing me to join in the debate on the motion which I rise in support of.

    Sir, indeed the battle against terrorism and JI in particular, is not one that many, including our Muslim compatriots here and in the region, will deny. The recurring bombings, calculated by these extremist elements to bring fear and terror to our civilised world, have once again brought

Column: 2105

this region into a state of war; albeit a war of a different sort. We are, today, faced with one of the toughest challenges yet since the days when we had to fight against the Communist insurgency.

    Like the fight against the Communists, the war on terror cannot be fought against known elements alone. For every Hambali or Bashir that we put into prison, there will be hundreds or even thousands of other similarly minded extremists who will be willing to rise in their place. Let us not under-estimate the extremity of hatred or feelings that these radicals have against others and its effect on their actions. What we have here is a very potent mix of religious and political convictions that so fill these terrorists that death, the very ultimate sacrifice of all, no longer serves as a sobering influence on conduct. In fact, for them, it is a glory to die. And, obviously, neither will it make a difference that innocent civilians, and we are talking here of children, and of loving fathers and mothers who feed these children, suffer from their harmful and despicable actions.

    Sir, perhaps the challenge we are faced with now is even greater than the challenge we faced from the Communist terrorists. Communism is a political ideology. We could deal with it in surgical fashion. We could ban Communism. We could isolate Communist guerillas by confining people in new villages. And we taught a whole generation of Singaporeans to believe that Communism is bad and is the very antithesis of freedom and wealth. Indeed, Communism has proven to be a bankrupt ideology. However, in the current fight against terrorism, we are faced with a very different enemy - people who practise terrorism in the name of religion. Sir, they are like cancers in our body that cannot be gotten rid of. We can only treat it. It may go into remission and one day, it may just rear its ugly head again.

    The problem here is the political and religious mix of Islam. Radical Islam has its roots in the Middle East conflict. The creation of the state of Israel in the post-war period, and the subsequent flood

Column: 2106

of predominantly Muslim Palestinian refugees into Jordan and elsewhere has been an underlying source of conflict and tension in the Middle East. That the Americans should be seen to cast their lot with the Israelis in this conflict throughout does not help with the perception that the Palestinians have been given an unfair deck of cards. Throughout this period, the Islamic revolution in Iran, together with the successful overthrow of the Soviet-backed regime in Afghanistan by the Talebans, served to provide new inspiration for the growth of fundamentalism in Islam. This was, in no small part, helped by the growing influence of Wahabism, which is another form of fundamentalist Islam.

    The over-arching reach of fundamentalist Islam worldwide cannot be ignored. In Southeast Asia, the force of Islam in the political realm cannot be ignored. For many states, particularly Malaysia and Indonesia, no serious political contender can hope to gain national prominence without paying close attention to the Muslim ground. In Malaysia, PAS, as an Islamic-based political party, has been gaining much political grounds in recent elections; and this despite their open espousal of eventually transforming Malaysia into an Islamic state based on the Syariah laws. Similarly, in Indonesia, Islamic-based political organisations, such as the NU, can often turn the political tide in an electoral contest. The influence of these organisations in Indonesia has grown quite dramatically in recent years and is a force to be reckoned with.

    Even in Singapore, the force of Islamic fundamentalism has not avoided us. That we see some Muslims in Singapore pushing their bounds with the State on their dress code in schools is but a variant of the mix between religion and politics. It is no accident that, in the last 20 years at least, we see more and more Muslims becoming more conservative in the doctrine and the practice of their faith. I know of many colleagues in my office who, over the years, have insisted on taking on the strict Islamic code of dressing. We also note that there is an increasing number of Muslim parents who

Column: 2107

are choosing to send their children to the madrasahs.

    Sir, in case I am misunderstood, I am not against any form of fundamentalism or conservatism in religious practice. In fact, I support it as the purist approach helps to keep a perspective on the original founding principles of the faith. What I am against is the insistence on one's right to practise and observe his beliefs even if it means the others may feel that their personal or common public spaces may be encroached or imposed upon. Additionally, I am against the practice of a faith in a manner that passes judgment on all others that they are infidels and are destined for the eternal hell.

    It is for this reason and for the sake of our social cohesion that we issue a call to our Muslim compatriots to be moderate in their faith. Sir, whilst nobody would deny the unassailable logic of the need to be moderate, there are several issues associated with the call that should perhaps be discussed further.

    First, the battle against terrorism is not confined simply to just arresting a few key suspects and dismantling the JI network. It goes beyond that. As with our battle against Communism, it is really about the battle for the hearts and minds of the people. A fertile ground for the spread of extremist ideas would always exist where social conditions permit. Communism thrives and spreads against a backdrop of abject poverty. The need for moderation is a function of the extent to which the affected social class perceives itself as being marginalised and disadvantaged. In other words, the greater the perception and reality that they are not beneficiaries of any progress or trickle of wealth that comes through the system, the greater is the likelihood of those affected, rejecting the legitimacy of the established regime and its leadership, and the need for moderation in their conduct. The bombings in the Philippines and Indonesia grew as much out of conditions of social desperation as it did of political and religious convictions. Let me put it another

Column: 2108

way. If the Philippines and Indonesia were in the same economic league as Australia and Japan, would the same extent of bombing incidents have taken place?

    In Singapore, we cannot say that our Muslim compatriots are a deprived group. However, the same cannot be said at the same time that there are no disparities in the socio-economic conditions among the Malay Muslims that there is no reason for us to be concerned. Over the years, we recognise that the social and political stability in Singapore can only come about if all ethnic groups moved together in reaping from the benefits of the progress in this country. Indeed, one underlying objective for establishing Mendaki is to ensure that the Malay Muslims in Singapore are not left behind as the country prospers. After more than 35 years of independence, one can confidently say that the gaps between the Malay Muslims and the other ethnic groups are closing. However, more can be done. There is still the perception that we are still some way off in all ethnic groups being on par on the economic terms.

    Sir, unfortunately, the disparity among the various ethnic groups tends to sharpen in focus in times when the economy moves into prolonged recession as our economy seems to be heading. The next few years will prove to be equally challenging as we struggle to recover from our present round of sluggish economic performance. Until then, there will be many who will be unemployed. Such conditions tend to reinforce the "them and us" mentality. If we are not careful, this may serve to deepen the fault lines in our society. Certainly, it does not help that some irresponsible parents could not have chosen a worse time to bring up the tudung issue. When the economic tide is down, the jetsam and the flotsam suddenly become all the more obvious for all to see. Such conditions provide the fodder with which to fuel the fire of extremist exploitation. If the people, by and large, are led to believe that their present plight is due not so much to structural economic problems but to the result of unfair Government policy, we have a

Column: 2109

problem on hand that the arrest of a few key trouble-makers is not going to resolve.

    This brings me to my second point. When we speak of moderate Islam, one question which arises is: who defines what is moderate Islam? And will the people, on whose shoulders lie the responsibility of defining moderate Islam, enjoy the legitimacy of authority within the target audience, or are they seen as just an extension of the regime that does not enjoy their trust and confidence?

    The Muslims in Singapore, as indeed Muslims all over the world, are subject to competing influences and doctrines. Just the other day, we read in the papers of how a fiery cleric was asked to leave London because of the inflammatory content of his sermon. Charismatic clerics, like this one, can pose a danger to society simply from their ability to influence masses through the power of their oratorical skills. If you have heard one of these fiery clerics preach, you would have known how persuasive and influential these preachers can be.

    Likewise, in Singapore, MUIS is concerned about the type of preachers who get invited to address the local congregation. We, too, recognise how much damage a radical and persuasive cleric can do to our social fabric. In the Internet age, we live in a borderless world. No amount of restriction and restraint is going to prevent radical Islam from spreading among and influencing the local people. Ultimately, whether the people who preach moderation will prevail will depend on their legitimacy in the eyes of the faithful. To the extent that these moderate leaders command the following and respect of the Muslims, there should not be any problem in holding the radicals at bay. However, the ability of the moderate leaders in a cosmopolitan society in holding the Muslims together will come under increasing pressure as the wave of fundamentalism continues to sweep across the Southeast Asian region.

    Muslim leaders in Singapore, whether they are politicians or religious leaders,

Column: 2110

operate within the constraints of a multi-racial society. It may not be possible for them at all times to impose on the larger society the specific demands of their faith. The issues of wearing the tudung in schools and the restriction of sale of alcohol are but some examples. The perceived inability to advance their specific demands arguably may compromise their moral authority and legitimate standing, in the eyes of the followers, to talk about matters of the faith. If this happens, the message from the moderate leaders to the Muslims to be moderate may not enjoy the same support and standing as one would have hoped for. The feared outcome is that despite the message for moderation, there may well be Muslims who will continue to nurse a silent respect for the Muslim terrorists who are prepared to die for their cause, thus lending a fertile ground for other Muslim teachers to teach otherwise.

    Obviously, in this battle, the State cannot be seen to have an active part in defining what moderate Islam is or should be, and neither the religious teachers who are expected to lead the way be seen to be agents of the State.

    Thirdly, social cohesion, even in the context of moderate Islam, cannot be strengthened if, as we have seen in recent years, the mosques continue to increasingly serve as a focal point for the Muslims in Singapore. As an MP on the ground, I cannot help but notice that many Muslims are increasingly retreating into the comfort zones of the mosques for their religious and other needs as well. I can only attribute this to the recent resurgence in Islam in Singapore, and this has inspired many to turn to the mosques. This has resulted in low participation rate for the secular communal activities among the Muslims at our grassroots organisations. Just look at the participation rate among the Muslims on the activities organised by community centres in Singapore today. I dare say that, without the benefit of a proper study, the number of Muslims participating in these activities can be improved, and the low number certainly is not welcomed.

Column: 2111



    This withdrawal, coupled with the recent events, certainly provide much room for unhealthy prejudices and misgivings among Singaporeans. For social cohesion to strengthen, Muslims in Singapore should not be seen to be setting themselves apart from the rest of society. Instead, they should be seen to be actively engaging the wider society in various activities in order to build more bridges so that whatever prejudices the others may have will disappear. Firm friendships and bonds must be engendered that go beyond the market and workplace. Token visits to each other's places of worship as an outer sign of promoting racial harmony should be expanded to include active interaction and exchanges. As loyal Singaporeans, we should make it a point to develop long-lasting and deep friendships with people who are not of the same colour of skin or of the same creed. Only then will we be able to disabuse ourselves and perhaps others of whatever prejudices that may have previously festered in our minds.

    Sir, this debate is not only about combating terrorism and the Jemaah Islamiyah in particular. I do not deny that these issues are important. This debate is also about the larger context within which the battle against terrorism is fought. This battle goes beyond the hunt for and the arrest of key JI or even Al-Qaeda suspects. To succeed, we must be mindful that, as in our fight against the Communists, we have to win the hearts and minds of those involved. For our Muslim compatriots, moderation in the practice of their faith must continue to remain the cornerstone of their belief, if we want to maintain racial and religious harmony in Singapore. For the non-Muslims, nursing unfounded prejudices and engaging in discriminatory practices is a recipe for disaster.

    Let us not forget that the flag which represents this country uses the red colour to signify the universal brotherhood of man. It should not matter that we are Muslims, Christians, Buddhists, Hindus or even free-thinkers. What matters most is that we are Singaporeans

Column: 2112

dedicated as a people towards building a country that we can all be proud of. The day we forget this principle would be the day when we go down the slippery slope of strife and racial tension. If that happens, Singapore will just be another sad statistic of a dream shattered.

    The cost is high, if we do not succeed in this battle. We must therefore strengthen our resolve to do whatever it takes, and to take whatever to do, to vanquish terrorism and all its attendant evil. We have no choice on this.

    Sir, I support the motion.

    Mr Zainul Abidin Rasheed (Aljunied): Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I rise in support of the motion in the name of the Minister for Home Affairs.

    Sir, I empathise with those who wish that the debate on this issue should not be prolonged, especially so for one who is the 13th speaker of the day! Enough is enough, some might say, both by Muslims and non-Muslims in Singapore. Perhaps, a sentiment felt more by the Muslim Singaporeans.

    But for those who believe so, Mr Wong's remarks earlier, I trust, would explain why this White Paper had to be presented to Parliament. Muslim Singaporeans should rest assured that this Paper is not about finding fault with the overwhelming majority of Muslims who are moderate and tolerant. Indeed, these Muslim Singaporeans themselves feel that they are the victims of this small group of misled Singaporeans who tried to hijack Islam.

    It bears reiterating that the majority of Muslim Singaporeans believe in living peacefully with others, especially in this plural, multi-racial and multi-religious Singapore. It will reassure the Muslims that this debate is not about finger-pointing Islam as the cause for all the ills brought about by the face of terror today. Yes, Muslims will be quick to point out that there is only one Islam, but they cannot deny that there are many faces of

Column: 2113

Muslims and many ways how Islam is interpreted or, worse, abused. Even here, there is room for better understanding among Muslims themselves, and also by the non-Muslims. There are many grey areas here, where black-and-white pronouncements might not be the quick answers towards better understanding.

    It is a long haul, and requires patience, perseverance and wisdom in handling it. It calls for continued confidence-building. It is not the form that matters. Yes, visits to mosques, temples, churches and clan associations must continue, dialogues on how to handle differences made a staple programme for grassroots organisations, but the underlying foundation to better understanding should be greater tolerance and acceptance in diversity. Race and religious relations should be inclusive rather than exclusive. Most importantly, a total rejection of terrorism, no matter what their causes.

    The White Paper in front of us for debate has called this threat of JI-types and of terrorism as a national one. Do enough Singaporeans know what that means? Do Singaporeans really know how serious the threat is? Judging from the reaction of some of whom I have met, I am not sure they do. For sure, not many Singaporeans have read the White Paper. We hope many more will follow the Parliamentary debate on the White Paper, as it is critical that as many Singaporeans as possible understand what holds.

    Singaporeans better believe that this threat is real. JI is real, and the threat of terrorism, whatever the cause, is real. Any sense of denial, as still held by some, will not help. However, this needs to be addressed, perhaps through more dialogues, even at grassroots level, as some generally responsible grassroots leaders do seem to still harbour such feelings of scepticism.

    At a recent Feedback Unit dialogue which I chaired, for example, there are still those who are sceptical about the findings, even to the point of doubting the integrity of the ISD. "Was force used?",

Column: 2114

they asked. "Why not charge them in open court, if there are already enough evidence?", they asked. I hope the booklet "Why the ISA", recently issued by the Ministry of Home Affairs, will help to explain and convince more why Singapore has to tackle the issue this way.

    For those not convinced, even the question of why no public confession was yet raised, despite the explanation given why such an approach was stopped following the experience of earlier ISA arrests. All these add to the notion how complex the issue is and why we need to continue to educate and reach out to more Singaporeans to make them understand how national this issue is and why it needs more careful handling.

    Muslim Singaporeans who still feel uneasy about them and their religion Islam being in the spotlight yet again, rest assured that it is more of the effort on the part of the Government to throw more light on the JI arrests, the JI members' operations, their psyche, their regional and global connections and their deadly dastardly schemes. For those who openly or secretly empathise with such suicidal terroristic methods of furthering the JI cause, think how you would feel if your own innocent flesh and blood fell victim to such bombings or attacks. If you say it is still all right, then the problem is even more serious.

    Some, although having accepted the threat of JI and terrorism, wondered why the Government prolonged the debate. "The sooner we close the matter, the better", fearing that the image of Muslim Singaporeans would be affected, not only locally but all over the world. They question the need to place the White Paper on sale and made available freely.

    Mr Deputy Speaker, Sir, I feel otherwise, as I agree with the need for the White Paper to be issued and debated. However, I trust the Minister will explain why the price was pegged at a high of $22 each when we would like it to reach more citizens.

Column: 2115



    I believe there are many Singaporeans who feel, "Oh, no, not another JI report!", or "Why place the Muslims under the spotlight again?" But I feel this White Paper should be made essential reading for as many Singaporeans as possible, if we want to ensure that the challenge of terrorism we face is understood as national. Teachers, community leaders, including religious leaders, need a good understanding of the issue and the role they can play to bring about better social cohesion. However, the White Paper needs to be reduced to simpler language and creative graphic representations to reach as many Singaporeans as possible.

    Muslim Singaporeans should feel reassured that the White Paper made it clear that the large majority of Singapore Muslims and Islam were not at fault. It is this small group of misguided JI-type Muslims which Muslim Singaporeans and non-Muslim Singaporeans alike are concerned about.

    It is worth reiterating that this is not a question of Muslims and Islam yet again under the spotlight. Thanks to ISD, also the regional security cooperation with the relevant authorities in Malaysia, Indonesia, the Philippines and many other international players, Singapore was able to nip the problem in the bud. The efficacy and good intentions of the ISD need not be doubted. Networks of terrorist destruction work in strange and most irresponsible ways. They care not lives of innocents, and rationalise such dastardly acts even with religious conveniences and mis-justifications.

    It is also noteworthy that the original tip-off that led to the JI arrests came from a Muslim Singaporean, just to emphasise that Muslims and non-Muslims alike will have to fight this battle together.

    Yes, the JI is Muslim-connected, so is the Al-Qaeda, but Muslim Singaporeans must be bold enough to reject them as their methods bring terror, not solution to the problems faced. The collective

Column: 2116

rejection of the JI and acts of terrorism by the more than 120 Muslim groups in Singapore bodes well for Singapore and our fight against extremism and terrorism.

    Non-Muslim Singaporeans, on their part, should remove any fear of Muslims or Islam in general and instead work hand-in-hand with the Muslim community to rid of this menace.

    Talking about ISD, Sir, I remember their professional work standards which Singapore can be proud of. Back in 1973, when the University of Singapore Muslim Society was invited by President Moammar Ghaddafi to attend the International Youth Conference, they knew about it. I had to convince the ISD officers that the University of Singapore Muslim Society representatives, including myself, were moderate Muslims, even though we were going to Libya, and that they have nothing to worry about. We were open and transparent about the matter but, despite that, both the USMS representatives were stopped at the airport on their return and all the publications were confiscated for checking.

    I was furious as they had doubted me and my loyalty, I thought, but on hindsight, was happy that they were thorough and professional in their conduct and work. During that two-week stay in Libya, many things happened. Yes, most of those who attended the conference were in search of answers for their troubled situations back home and in the Muslim world. Where was the answer promised by Islam? There were so many double standards and hypocracies felt in international relations. It was true then, and I am sure you will say the same for now. Ghaddafi had proposed Islam as the Third International Theory, where he said that capitalism and Communism had failed, and brought about the Green Book, as his answer to the world's predicaments. Most of the delegates rejected the theory and the conference ended in failure, much to the chagrin of the host.

    Delegates then participated in demonstrations, peaceful though, on the streets

Column: 2117

of Tripoli for the Palestinian cause and some were even approached to serve in the shadow cabinet-in-exile for the Moros of the Philippines. There were lots of sympathies for many causes of the Muslim then world-wide, but that did not make us, in fact, most delegates, see the need to go the JI way or to resort to terrorism.

    The serious threat of misconceived "Jihad" or "Holy War", is real, even till today.

    Mr M J Akbar, writing in his book, The Shade of Swords, Jihad and the Conflict between Islam and Christianity, concludes that "Defeat (of Osama and Al Qaeda and the Talebans) is only a setback in the holy war. The Jihad goes on". However, that should not alarm us, as it is not new. The power of jihad, for some, pervades the mind and soul of Islam. The mind is where the current battle will be fought, and this is why it will be a very long war.

    Muslim Singaporeans should realise that they should not be pawns, nor proxy, to such battles. The lesson from Pakistan is clear.

    After a bloodbath separation from India to form its own country of majority Muslims, it is now seen as a hotbed of this battle of the mind. M J Akbar wrote that Pakistan has become a haven of terrorists who have created "a state within a state". He said that no one said this more clearly than President Pervez Musharraf, when in an address to the nation a year ago, asked for an end to the culture of jihad. He told the extremist clergy that they must stop encouraging gullible young men into martyrdom, as he would not want Pakistan to take the responsibility for jihad across the world. He would not allow mosques to be misused and seminaries to become schools for hatred.

    In Malaysia too, the ruling government has begun its crackdown on rural religious schools (SARs) that sow hatred against the government by withdrawing funding.

    Fortunately, for Singapore, the bad influence was marginal and had been

Column: 2118

nipped in the bud. Nevertheless, it happened and can happen again. It is therefore the duty of all to ensure such tendencies do not repeat.

    MUIS and local Muslim groups and leaders have done well in responding to the call to reject extremist views and acts of terrorism. The Malay MPs have stated unequivocally their position to reject the JI and its extremist agenda. Together with the Malay community, they have pledged to continue to work with other Singaporeans to bring about a more cohesive, multi-racial and multi-religious society. Realising that the fight against terrorism and extremism will be a long-drawn affair, the Malay MPs call on everyone, Malays and non-Malays alike, to stand up and work together to strengthen mutual trust and confidence and move on as a nation.

    When I was in Delhi in November, I learned that further bloodshed was avoided when the Muslim organisations came out in force to condemn the violent and terrorist attacks by extremist Muslim groups on the Hindu community in Gujerat.

    Similarly, following a denial mode in Indonesia from most Muslim groups, the Bali bomb blast of October 12 jolted them to work alongside the Government to fight terrorism. This, I was told, avoided a very serious backlash between the majority Hindus in Bali and the minority Muslims on the island.

    Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore have this unique opportunity to work together to remove such unhealthy radicalism among fringe Muslim groups. This is a battle we do not have to, and cannot fight alone. I would like to urge the Government to enhance regional cooperation so as to ensure that no one group can abuse the common borders for any terrorist attacks. There are more that can be done in terms of regional cooperation in this fight against terrorism, and we certainly look forward to our neighbours sharing this sense of urgency.

Column: 2119



    Sir, on a final note, we must do all we can to find ways to make both our Muslim Singaporeans and non-Muslim Singaporeans to be at ease with each other. Yes, there will be a certain amount of awkwardness, as mentioned by Mr Wong just now, but let that be just a passing wind. Let us look to the IRCC and Harmony Circles to bridge better relations and understanding at the HDB heartland. More Malays/Muslims should use this opportunity to improve the level of participation at the grassroots level. There is now an unprecedented demand for a better understanding about the Malay-Muslim way of life and the Malays/Muslims should not waste this opportunity for better bridging and better understanding.
